text: Aroma and flavor is grainy malts, mild caramel, a bit of sweetness in the middle and a slightly tart/mostly smooth finish.
Reviewed from notes: pours a orange like amber color with off-white head. Caramel and roasted malts all over the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with malty goodness.

This beer has unique history. It was originally brewed in honor of Joe Kuehn who had recently died in a plane accident while on his way fishing in Canada. Joe built Plastic Ingenuity from the ground up and he also kept Capital Brewery afloat in the early years. He was a great supporter of local brewerys.
Great color and aroma, nice finish. Drank it out of a bottle, so I cant comment on th e color and head.
12 oz bottle...this would be from last year,  so Im guessing this has been sitting a while.  Its an ok beer....not one of the better Marzens in my opinion,  but certainly not a bad tasting beer.

12ounce bottle that purs an amber orange color with minimal white head.  Aromas of malt, caramel, and a touch of grass.  Flavor is the same with a touch of banana at the end.  Enteresting bet for a summer seasonal, would have expected this to be an autum/fall release.
Bottle. Slightly hazy light orange pour with a thinner white head. Aroma and taste of caramel malt, banana, and yeast. Pretty darn good. Strange style for a summer seasonal but really, who cares.
Im not getting anything special. malts are rich enough, hops are too grassy for this style. not enough character.

12 ounce bottle from Steves Mineral Point in Madison. Pours a clear amber with a thin white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel and toasted malts. The taste is caramel, grain, grassy hops banana and other faint fruits. Medium bodied.

The aroma is nothing special with adjuncts, dust, grass, and cardboard. The appearance is light amber with a nice head. The taste is better than the aroma with lots of malt and a bit of toffee in the finish. The palate is average. Overall a good beer.
am i the only one that thinks its odd that a oktoberfest is only available during the summer? oh well. a perfectly serviceable one it is actually.
Confusing now that theres an oktoberfest out in a similar bottle.  But not bad.
Tried this beer at the Casanova Beer Cave Festival (2011), nice golden color, pleasant taste.

I can tell you this is not the time Im usually divulging into this style, but hey it IS the Capital Brewery summer seasonal, yes summer. It comes in a 12 oz twist-off bottle (still dont know why Capital doesnt have the pry-off).

It pours into my mug a decent light amber/caramel/golden color with a foamy, white head that dissipated pretty luckily leaving no lace.

The smell is like a lot of American Oktos, malty with a sense of almost cola in the scent but with a distinctly more German flair. The malts are malty and springy.

The taste has a boat load of saltine cracker like grain with some nuttiness but not a ton. The hops leave a leveling bitterness which works nicely. It is a bit lighter and waterier than most in a way, but in a good way. The hops seem different here than in most oktoberfest beers.

Overall this is a good depiction of the style, slightly altered.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-16-2010 01:34:49

Amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is nobly hopped with caramel, toasted malt and some German hops too.  Caramel, toasted malt and a touch of hops  just not very flavorful.  Easy drinking and thin, Im a fan of most Capital beers, but this one misses the mark.
Pours a hazy golden with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet, grainy malt. Flavor is grainy, cereal, lightly sweet, not what I would expect for an Okto.

[Bottle] Pours a clear golden/amber color with a small amount of white head. Aroma of grains, some light grass and corn. The taste is of sweetgrass, light biscuit malts and a bit of caramel. The mouthfeel was a little on the light side. Didnt seem to have all the marzen character that I was looking for either. Nevertheless, it was an easy drinking session beer.

On tap @ UNOs in Madison.
Dark gold pour with a thin white head.
Aroma was rich toffee and roasted maltiness. 
Flavour was again nice deep caramel/toffee, some hints of molassess and earthy roasted maltiness. Light earthy mown hay hop in the finish.

flavor is beginnings of kolsch like peach that moves to well developed toffee. aroma starts similarly then malt dominates but here it shows some corn elements, luckily lost in the flavor (for the most part).  appearance is translucent deep amber, darkened past gold. low carb, little head and touches of lacing.

12oz bottle pours a clear orangey gold with a live, effervescent white head that lasts about three blinks.  Aroma is light, a bit like corn, with subtle yeast and Bavarian hops.  Flavor is equally simple, laden with straightforward malt and enough of those hops to balance things out.  Nice and smooth, but a bit overcarbonated.  Nice, but Im not sure that its world-class.

12oz bottle at IHG during the move on free burger night! Fest beer, really? As I was drinking this I kept thinking this was just a pale lager. Not that it was bad or offensive, just very delicate and light on typical fest beer flavors.

This is over rated. Darker yellow pour is marred by the head that dies quickly. Sweet, corny aroma with metallic notes. Sweet, corny flavor with metallic notes. Goes down quick, cold, and smooth, but so does the average macro light beer. This is over rated. On tap at Jimmys Del Bar.

Bottle - Fest returns! A beautiful amber pour with a small white head. Aroma is lightly toasted malt, rich and bready, with herbal hops melding perfectly into a nice balance. Taste is a bit watered down, but very smooth and malty. Clean through the finish, where the herbal hops kick in and bitter it just a bit. Terribly simple, but terribly refreshing, I underestimated this one a bit. Capital has done a great job of bringing back their good beers. They can sell all the Rustic and Island Wheat and Supper Club they want--just sell the good stuff, too.

If memory serves me correctly, only 50 ratings ago I made note and I quote "I hope someday soon Capital beer comes back to Iowa. I miss it." How grateful I was to find three varieties of Capital beer in a local shop today. It seems as though luck has shined upon us here in downtown Des Moines. The beer pours just a shade darker than deep golden heading in the orange territory but not quite there yet. The head is big, full, tight, billowy, and leaves a nice enough although somewhat spotty lace. The aroma is classic Märzen in every respect. That dominant mildly roasty mildly caramelized, primarily grainy and fresh maltiness. Of course coupled with those perfect herbal and earthy hoppy notes. Something about this aroma seems rustic and rural. The sorts of aromas you catch on a breezy day on a country drive. The flavor is richly malty and well balanced with plenty of herbal hoppiness. Each sip begs you almost do the palate double take. It starts off with a fruity and bright malt character with some deep notes of roastiness and some mild caramel. About the time you are to declare this a rich malty beer the hops just kick right into gear with that nice unforgiving type of bitterness and the awesome herbal notes of bitter herbs and horehound. I will admit it took me a bottle and a half to feel as strongly as I do about this beauty, but it was well worth the effort.

12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear, golden colored body with a thin, white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is some pale malt sweetness and a bit corny. A light floral and grassy hop with a touch of bread and fruity, apricot-citrus. Flavor is similar. Somewhat floral and fruity up front with some pale malt sweetness and a touch of caramel. I get just a pinch of toast with a somewhat bready malt in there too. Finishes crisp with some floral fruits and a light grass with a light bitterness that gives off just a hint of earth. Dry with a moderate aftertaste following a light to medium body and moderate carbonation. Overall, an easy drinking beer. Not quite what I look for in an Oktoberfest, but decent. This is definitely anything but special, but it was pleasant enough.

Welcome back - its been too long!  From bottle as this years summer seasonal!  Pours orange-amber with fluffy white head.  Some serious carbonation flowing up.  Aroma of fresh hops and sweet caramel malts.  Clean bitter hops up front fading to a beautiful malt backbone of toasted and caramel undertones.  Slightly dry finish, medium mouthfeel.  A solid German-style lager.  About as close to an Oktoberfest as youll get this time of year.

Amber with light, white head / Nose of toast and burnt sugar / Light to medium body, balanced with a touch of hop creaminess, and a decent finish / Light, muddy flavors of burnt sugar and toasted grain / A pleasant enough beer.

Pours a golden body with a pretty malted aroma. Also has an akwardly overly malted flavor which was at first a little unpleasesnt. Flavors of soft berries, oak and grain. I may have to try this again.

12oz, twist-off bottle, black with gold label.  Light amber color.  Sweet malt aroma.  Spicy herbal grass hop aroma.  Flavor is sherry, allspice, even some black pepper spiciness.  Finishes with a clean hop bitterness to balance out the malt character.  Very nice.

Date: 03/15/2008
Mode: bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party

Appearance: hazy dark gold, fine beige head, streaks of drippy lace, 
Aroma: earthy aroma with a caramel sweetness and a slight metalic edge, 
Flavor: sweet caramel malt flavor, nice bready character, lots of earthyness for balance, light bitter finish, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

Pours a light copper color with a white head  Aroma is tons of caramel and malt.  Then finishes with some nice peppery hops.  Flavor is big on the malt and caramel. With nice peppery hop finish to help balance it out.
Caramely roasted aroma and flavor. Light malt.Has good clean smooth finish.
Im fairly sure i had this and not the oktoberfest, as the bottle just said FEST on it. Pretty typical, clean o fest brew, not bad. Decent hop bite for marzen as well. not bad.
This is easily my favorite beer.  The flavor gets better as you drink more.  Very smooth, malt, caramel and not too thick.  I love it and cant wait for it to come back!

Not a huge fan of Oktoberfest style but it wasnt bad. This beer was really hyped up to me and I am failing to see why. Pretty run of the mill and definately nothing special. Pretty good just didnt live up to what I heard about it.

Tasted 10/10/07.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a golden hue.  Noisy effervescence.  Slight ring of white head.  Acceptable bready caramel nose.  Light to medium bodied with overt effervescence.  Caramel malts and tingling acidic citrus hops.  Off dry and mildly sticky.  Slight fruity flavor.  Slight bitterness.  Too hoppy.  Only a moderate attempt.  Touch watery.  Ever so slight apple note.  Meh...

Bottle, courtesy Bockyhorsey. Poured an amber color, very generous initial head with solid retention, nice lacing. The aroma was grassy hops and some caramel. Flavor was grassy hops over top of caramel and pilsner-like qualities, bread and honey. An added spiciness, yet the grassy hops reappear in the aftertaste (Saaz?) and keep this from being anything vienna-like. Not my preferred take on a marzen, yet for what it was, quite nice. Mouthfeel was malty / carbonated. Thanks, Bill and Wendy!

pours yellow with a one finger fluffy white head. aroma is malt with some hops and a little corn. has a light body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger. has a dry hop aftertaste it is not bad but nothing special. has some sediment floating around, kind of a souped up pilsner/ pale ale/ marzen. now as it warms some caramel malt and orange peel show up in the flavor and aroma. so i am bumping up the scores a little and the hops show up a little more also.

Bottle. Dominated by malts, this Oktoberfest beer is smooth and enjoyable. Light amber color with a small, off-white head. Bready, grainy aroma with notes of sweet caramel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. Nicely carbonated. Smooth texture and medium bodied.

In a shaker from the tap.  Pours a light amber / pale orange color.  Thin head that disappears.  Malty, slightly fruity taste.  A clear finish, and bitterness that makes this a good Marzen, if a bit fizzy in mouthfeel.

12 ounce bottle. Shaker glass. Cloudy yellow with a medium head. Aroma - grain and citrus. Flavor was malty with some caramel and a sort of fruitiness I could not put my finger on. Maybe a hint of orangle peel. Some bitterness and a crisp tangy mouthfeel. This one kind of grows on you.
Grainy, corny aroma, and a grainy, corny flavor. Tasty, and uncomplicated. Mildly peppery finish. Thanks to Buckybeer for the trade!

sampled on tap during the tasting portion of their tour, i didnt take much notes but almost all the beers tasted extremely similar. nose of biscuit and noble hops. flavor of biscuit, cookie, and hops. straight forward and drinkable.

Poured a nice amber with a medium sized head that left no lace.  Aroma of grass and bittering hops.  Taste was that of lightly rosted malts along with wome wheat and hop afterbite.  A good drinking summer beer, more of a marzen rather than oktoberfest though.

7/27/2007:  Capital Fest Beer is extremely pale amber (more like a golden/light orange) in color with a frothy off-white head.  It is very clear with a moderate+ level of carbonation.  When did Oktoberfest beers become so light and fizzy in appearance?!  The aroma has a slightly European maltiness to it that is overshadowed by honey (actually, the honey seems to disappear as the beer warms up a little bit).  Again, it just doesnt seem quite right for an Oktoberfest beer...  Well, the appeance and aroma might be slightly off to me, the the flavor is pretty close!  Very malty and smooth with flavors of toasted malt, biscuit, and a hint of that smooth and tasty European lager characteristic.  It finishes clean and slightly with a noticeable noble hop presence.  Very nice.  The body of this beer is medium-light to medium and appropriate for the style.  The taste of this beer has rekindled memories of Oktoberfest in Muchich and restored my interest in what seems to be a style that has long since morphed from what it used to be...
12 oz bottle from buckybeer.  Thanks Mark.  I appreciate it!  Rating #119 for this beer...

12 oz bottle. Poured a clear golden-light orange color. Head was bubbly, off white and reduced over a minute or two to a thin film. Not much lace was left behind. Aroma was of grassy hops and malty cereal grain. Spicy and dry with subdued noble hops, sweet corn, and ample carbonation. Not bad.

12 oz. bottle, labeled "Capital Fest Beer." Pleasant, malty aroma features honey, grape juice, and cookie elements, all of which are also present in the flavor. Pours a clear, sparkling gold with a moderate amount of off-white head. Paler in color than most Oktoberfest beers. Produces extensive lacing. Tastes like a cross between a traditional Oktoberfest and a German pilsner. Biscuity, lightly toasted malt flavor. Dry, hoppy finish. Moderate body. Oily, crisp, and lively in the palate. Easy to drink. Capital Fest Beer is a good, refreshing lager. Im not a big fan of the Oktoberfest style, so I appreciate the pilsner-esque character of this example.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Bockyhorsey - Pours a hazy golden color with a one finger thick off white head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is toasty malt and esters.  Flavor is toasted malt with a tad bit of friutiness.  Palate is smooth.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Bill and Wendy.

Pours medium gold with a whispy white head. Pretty big carbonation. Little bubbles sticking all around the side of the glass. Aroma is light raw malts, hints of citrus, hops, corn and wheat. Smells of a cold morning dew. Flavor is sweet malts, candied corn, light hops. This one was very nice.
Clear amber with large quickly diminishing head.  Same old Capital aroma, slight malt.  Flavor is red apple, a little citrus.  Crisp med body with little carb.  Same old, same old.
Great summer beer.  Not too sweet, not too heavy.  Nice floral aromas.  Good clean finish.

Thanks Steve!  Found this one bottled in Baraboo, Wisconsin.  Golden, reddish bour with a thick, white head.  Nice, floral hoppy aroma, but a very fruity -- not sweet -- taste throughout.  Champagne, grapes and banana are prevalent.  Finished clean.  Very drinkable.  Excellent!
Clear honey colored beer with sparse head.  Lots of carbonation.  Faint malty nose.  Sweet malty taste with a refreshing characteristic.  Carbonation kind of bites at my tongue.

Bottle. Poured a golden yellow with an off white head. Aroma was grainy, Light hop and floral aroma. Taste was hoppy, grainy. Bitter Saaz like hops. Very hearty, substantial body creating a great mouthfeel. Germans have nothing up on this one. Good Maerzen.

Picked up single bottle from the Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a light coppery amber brew with a lumpy white head that dissolves to a fine film. Nice lacing. Aroma is sweet oktoberfest caramel, malted barley with some rich bready grain, with some peach character. Taste is medium body, a little dryer than a regular oktoberfest, some stickiness, and a sweet bitter aftertaste.  A great beer to celebrate graduation with those kids at UW-Madison!

Pours honey colored w/ a splash of orange. A shallow, semi creamy froth emerges and reduces quickly to reveal a thin canopy w/ brewers lace. Aroma has a sharp malty profile w/ a little citrus and sulpher. Light to medium nectar w/ ample residual effers creates a soft fiberous cotton like texture. Very nice. Perectly balanced malt and hop ratio w/ mild caramel, citrus and hay. The finish is bittered better than moderate w/ extended flavors of grainy malts. Overall: I really liked the texture and the bitternes to malt ratio. I lost it on the finish w/ the grain. Although a good beer indeed.
Amber color.  Smell of malt, hops, Asti champaige, and some spicey fruit.  Taste of malt, spicey citrus, hops, alcohol and a decent bitterness at the end.
I hate this brew along with many others made by this unfortunate brewery that hogs space at many local taverns in my area.  Tastes decent at first, but man what horrible peppery aftertaste.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours gold with an off-white head. Aroma of sweet malts and grain. The flavor is sweet, grainy, and a slight bitterness. Good beer.

Bottle.  Slightly hazy, honey brown with a small but thick head.  Grain and malt aroma.  Flavor is more malt with a mild, fruity spiciness.  Crisp from start to finish with a nice medium body but a bit more carbonation than Id prefer.  The taste is a bit grainier than I expected from a marzen but still very good.

Bottle poured orange with a nice thick head.
Aroma of corn and malt with a flavor to match.
Had a bit of wet dish rag taste on the palate with a crisp tangy finish.

Poured an amber hued golden with a foamy white head that settled into thin cake-like lacing, small amount of ringed sticking.  Has a aroma of hops, a very subtle banana with a light touch of caramel. Taste was a balance of mild spice, a light fruitiness and crisp marzen malts with a medium body, good carbonation. 
A very nice offering from Capital, very drinkable and a good spring/summer marzen beer to share with friends.

Grainy, malty, watery, acidic mineral note. semi sweet blandness. aftertaste doesnt work. I thought this style would be sweet spot of this brewery  but they blew this. Big step down from caps special pils or munich dark

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one from his west coast connection. Pours copper\golden with a decent size off-white head. Aroma of sweet malts, hops, and grain. The flavor is smooth, sweet, with a slight bitter finish. Not a bad brew.
in bottle. dark gold with medium white head that disappears quickly. Grainy acrid aroma. candy-like sweetness with a watery finish. thin fizzy palate that whimpers away.

12oz bottle pours a dark copper with a head that fades to a thin ring.  A few small but nice aromas  come out, nutmeg, bread, and malt.  It has a light body with a slight creaminess to it.  The flavor is mostly amber malt and a little bready with a slightly bitter finish.

Clear gold body that fails to prevent the average sized head from collapsing prematurely. 
Very little aroma.
Malty flavor with a touch of hop bitterness. Low carbonation and light body make this an easy drinker.

Bottle. Aroma has a malt sweet fruit aroma. Golden body with white head. Body flavor is mainly medium sweet malt blend. Some fruit in flavor but hard to dintingish what maybe oranges. Medium sweet palate. Beer had a complexity to it, intriging.

Very pleasant aroma, somewhat wheat-like.  Appears reddish-amber, very little carbonation. The flavor is weaker than I was expecting, but the palate is very smooth. Overall, a good beer, but not an excellent one.

Deep golden hue, nice lasting off-white head.  Smell is a little over sweet, but nice fruit and caramel notes to it.  Hop bitterness gives a cleanness to the caramel notes that predominate.  Mouth feel is alomost chewy due to the carbonation.  Solid beer.

Bottled.  Poured a clear medium golden with just the faintest hint of orange in there... tall white head receded to an 1/8" layer after a couple minutes.  Nose was of toasty (and possibly smoky) caramel, toffee, dried apricots, and other fruity esters.  Flavor picked up toasty caramel throughout... with fruits around the edges, some leafy bitterness, and toffee.  Very creamy, almost buttery on the palate... with just the right level of bitterness.  Almost tacky at the finish, but held it together.  This was a really tasty brew!

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2006 This is an exceptional marzen. Being of German heritage, Oktoberfest is a wonderful time to let my inner beer-lover out. It pours a nice gold with a decent offwhite head. It smells wonderfully malty and tastes the same. This is a really smooth beer with no aftertaste. Bold flavor, no aftertaste? Sweet.
On tap at brewery:  Golden yellow with light tan head.  Slightly bitter.  Some malt and spice in aroma.  Light bodied.  Slightly sweet, maybe grape.  Kind of basic.

Pours a hazy light gold with a thin white head that leaves some lacing.  The aroma is sweet malt with a sour background.  An underwhelmingly sweet flavor upfront.  Malty with a bitter finish.  It is fizzy and watery in the mouth.  Nothing amazing.

12oz bottle. Poured a medium and slightly cloudy golden color with a huge (4 finger) sized white head. Aromas of yeast and bread. Tastes of bread and honey. I didnt really get too much more out of this one.

(Bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malt, pumpkin spice, breadiness, and a hint of nutmeg.  Flavor of malt, caramel, some spices, and touch of cocoa is it hits room temperture.
Very passable beer.  I would never decline an offer for any Capital brews, especially this one or Autumnal fire
Pours dark golden with nice white head. Nice lacing. Faint sweet caramel malt with some metallic character. Flavor has lots of sweet malt and residuel sugar with same metallic like character.

golden color w/ a tall fluffy white head some lace.  yeast and hints of carmel some alcohol.  avg pal some carb ok body.  A decent little fest beer w/ some honey and careml in the falvor w/ some yeast to it not much else..

Clear amber with a fleeting off-white head.  Subtle aroma of yeast, caramel, malts, a hint of alcohol.  Medium bodied with gentle carbonation and a smooth feel in the mouth.  The flavor was clean and crisp but nothing spectacular.  Just a pleasant drink.

(12oz bottle) Clear golden body with small off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, bread, some caramel, light pepper.  Taste is medium sweet, bread, caramel, light earthy/floral/herbal.  Dash of alcohol in a light-medium body.  I am not a fan of the style generally, but this one wins me over with its well-rounded and balanced flavor.

Pours to a nice golden body with a huge foamy white head and excellent lacing.  The aroma is very bready.  Sweet malts.  Kinda smells like sweet rolls.  Maple syrup.  The flavor is a nice tasting Okfest.  Spicy sweet caramel malts, almonds, toffee.  The palate is medium modied with a slick feel.  Blends very nicely in this beer.  Pick this one up!  Im not a huge Okfest fan, but this is really good.
Pours a golden color.  Smells of sweet malt and straw.  Tastes of sweet caramelly malt.  Pretty smooth and tasty.

Light amber colour.  Light bready aroma with a hint of sulphur.  A gentle but crisp hoppiness, shot of alcohol and clean-if-light, well-extracted bready malt triumvirate.  Well-structured, clean, simple...a fine version of the modern-day Oktoberfest style.  Would that they make them this well in Munich.
More robust than Caps oktoberfest. Smooth and malty. Shirt and shoes are required at all times.

Bottle: Golden, translucent, medium white foamy head, spotty lacing, light carbonation. &nbsp Malty/grassy nose, hints of cereal. &nbsp Mild malty start, slight astringent bitterness emerges towards the finish. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Fairly clean finish. &nbsp This one seems to me to be somewhat light, not very robust, but its fairly clean and easy to kick back.

Aroma is nutty, pepper and vanilla with some caramel and maple accents.  Flavor is smooth almonds and caramel malts with a slight spicy Oktoberfest tingle.  Some oak cask qualities.  Hint of chocolate malts paired with the crisp reflex of pilsner malts.  Heads above Capitals other Oktoberfest offering.  Very pleasing.

Aroma has sweet caramel and toffee with a lot of fruityness.  Clear copper-orange color with a white head that fades.  Nice caramel flavor, slightly sweet but just a hint of bitterness in the finish...not sure if I would call it bitterness, just not-sweetness.  Medium body with a water-smooth texture and slightly metalic finish.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2005 A festive beer that is a jumble of tastes, textures, and tinges of an assortment of different styles.  Nose is swampy and fruity, and this translates in taste to flavors of cantaloupe, yeast, roasted corn, and apricot, all with a buttery mouthfel.  These flavors fade to a general spiciness, which in turn gives way to a creamy, caramel malt.  The malt isnt quite sweet... candy-sour and funky are the best words, I suppose.  The aftertaste is light, but lingering, a watery swill-brew taste.
Tastes just like all the other Capitol beers.  No hop flavor, not hop bitterness, and no beer body!  Sorry, I dont care to drink this beer at all.

Dark gold to pale amber in color. Head is slight but extremely rich, leaving plenty OK off-white lacing. Typical malt-hop imbalance aroma, slightly acrid, not a good balance overall. Flavor is buttery (more precisely "like margarine", but American Midwesterners will refer to margarine as butter so I suppose I may as well). The imbalance continues but the hops seem to win out, allowing compromised elements of honey and corn flakes to show. This brewery puts out much better -- maybe I got a bad bottle, Im going to try again from another source and update this rating if necessary.
Copper.  Nose caramel, bready.  Big malts, sweet toffee, slightly smoky.  Richer than expected for the style, but quite good.

I was not impressed with this beer.  I like all the other beers from capital, but this is by far my least favorite.  I dont know if the beer was old or I just dont like this style of beer, but that is yet to be proven.

Very little hop and malt aroma.  NIce appearance, orange with a lace that lasts until the end of the beer.  Flavors of malt, yeast, and bread.   The malt is dominant and there is a lot of it.  Dry aftertaste.

First I do not agree that this is an Oktoberfest, a Vienna yes, but not an Oktoberfest.  Capital produces some of the finest Lagers in the world and this is a fine example.  A bold golden brown color with a smallest white head.  A strong caramel malt aroma with an almost meadow like grass background.  A slightly sweet taste with a grassy hop flavor that finely balances this beer.  Alot of body and taste in what many consider an inferior style.  This brewery knows what they are doing.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2005 (12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with hopdog, thanks Steve!) This is a pretty nice little Oktoberfest.  In both the flavor and the nose, its malty, bready, toasty and slightly caramely, but also a bit too sugary sweet as well, which is what Im less enthused about.  Medium bodied and nicely carbonated.  Light golden amber in color and slightly hazy in appearance.  The off-white head is pretty small initially, and fades to a small rim fairly quickly, leaving on a few dots of lace on the glass.  Decent, but if Im in the mood for an Oktoberfest, Id probably not reach for this one because there are several I enjoy more.

A nice spicy, very quaffable brew.   Best enjoyed outside at the bier garten.  The beer is a little drier than the Octoberfest, but lacks a bit of the body.  Color is richer than the beer, more of an amber.  Very clean on the tongue, and with enough maltiness to please.
Pours is a murky brown.  Aroma is spicey and peppery. Flavor is molasses and lots of malt.  The after taste is hoppy and fruity with the right amount of spice. A very tasty brew.
Very little head with a nice gold color. Malty taste that has a clean aftertaste. A nice beer.

With a beer this good, why produce an "Octoberfest"?  Skip the Octo, get the Fest while its still available.  Color is more of an amber, big malt, nicely balanced hops, some fruit, but just so FLAVORFUL, Ill miss this beer until the 05 release.  Another fine Capital product.

Draft. I get more impressed by Capital each time I have one of their beers. This has a lovely amber-auburn color. I wont rate the head, since I poured this out of a growler. Also, because its from a growler, not much in the way of bubbles, but still a good fizziness. A very well malted Okto flavor leaving some stickiness, and well-matched hops. Consider how many German brewers are making Oktoberfests that look more like Heineken, and savor this one.

Appearance: bright, light peachy hue, with a modest, though sizzling off-white head.
Lively aromatics! Zesty, fruity, peachy, citrusy, and very tasty!
Light hops, but warm, happy, friendly flavor.
Tangy taste, decent texture. Medium body, sweet, long finish.
Very much enjoyed! Tasted like a pale ale, but lacked the body and hoppiness. Howd they do this with a lager? Quite enjoyable! Whatever the occasion is, Ill happily toss back a Fest in celebration!

Small white head, reddish orange body. Dominant perfume aroma accompanied by orange and caramel. Good flavor, a little sweet but has enough balance to keep it interesting. Mmm... sweetened earthy hops like tobacco leaves and caramel. Sticky mouthfeel. Pretty good stuff.

Lightly malty, perfumy aroma, like milky caramel and flowers, with a bit of herbal hop underneath.  Light-medium orange-amber color, filtered, with a creamy head.  Flavor is very well balanced, the caramel malt sweetness tempered by mildly earthy, herbal, fruity hop flavors.  Bitterness remains low, however.  Finish is lively and refreshing.  Smooth palate, body is medium.  Incredibly drinkable, overall a nice take on the style.  Better than this brewery's Oktoberfest.

12 oz bottle.  Clear orangish copper, just a bit of lasting head.  Big malt nose, caramel and grapefruit and berries; malty, somewhat woody body, molasses and pungent herbs which show up late.  Excellent, full-bodied, enormously flavorful.
A nice malty "fest" with enough hops to balance.  Not a style I like all that much, but this is pretty good.  Id drink it again.
Cloudy Orange Coloring.  Malt, Yeast, Fruity.  Had a bottle that may have been around...Need to try again...but still very good.

Not typically my favorite style, but this is a tasty, quaffable winner.  Lightish faded copper color.  Fine, sticky head.  Malty, toasty, spicy aromas.  Very malty flavors without being too sweet.  Great spicy hop balance.  Appropriately named.

Bottle pours a hazy rust with a decent head and some lace.  The aroma is of malty, bread like, and some hops.  The flavor is fresh bread, slightly sour, and not much in the way of noticable hops.  The palate is fairly rich for a Marzen.  Overall, a good effort by the folks in Middleton.

Pours from the bottle with a light orange and red color. A little bit of lacing and very little head. Smells of oak, maple and a little urine cake. Tastes like toffee, chocolate and is fairly sweet. An enjoyable brew for warm weather.

Paler type of fest, orangey amber.  Medium head.  Toffeeish and melanoidins mildly present.  Sweetish and toffeeish but with a somewhat empty and almost watery finish.  Hops add balance but no flavors.  Fairly boring.

Lightly hazy orange/bronze color with very light head & carbonation. The aroma is nicely malty with some fresh hops & citrusy caramel. The flavor is lightly sweet with light hop bitterness & some malts & nutty cutrus flavors. Finishes balanced & herbal. Good! Thanks Falconseye!

Cloudy amber pour with a thin film of white head and sparse lacing. Heavy malts in the nose along with some spice. Earthy hops. Flavors go from a sweet caramel malt up front to a sharply bitter finish at the end. Spices dash around through out the beer. Tangy palate.
Dark golden color. Big malty aroma. This beer comes off very heavy, not very summer like. Malty flavor profile with very little bitterness.

Deep golden to light amber colour. Lovely pleasant maltiness delicately balanced by a mild hoppiness. The sweetness also has a fine strawberry like fruitiness than I (but noone else) sometimes find in very good malty beers. Extremely pleasant and a great example of the style but perhaps not complex enough for a real top rating (4+).

Hazy, golden color with a lasting white head.  Medium carbonation.  Malty taste with touches of yeast and lemon.  Quite a different Oktoberfest, I almost thought of it as an attempt at a Belgian!  Very nice brew.

Dark bronze colour, big sweet, malty aroma. Slightly roasted malt flavour which turns sweet, then ends with only slight bitterness. Thick as well. I love malty beers so it works really well for me. Thanks Slikwily
Man, I love how capital Brewery's beers smell.  This is a smooth Fest, wtihout any real bite.  Oh well, beer is beer, and drunk is what this beer will soon be, as will I.
Copper, with a white head. Sweet malty aroma. Bready caramel flavor, touch of honey. Very on style.

Lightly golden colour, thin persistent head.  Deep doughy yeast fills the aroma, along with lightly oily hops, pine and lemon zest.  Good amount of spice on the palate - pepper, nutmeg, hay and more dough.  Lingering maltiness that rounds out the flavours very well.

Aroma - malty.  Appearance - golden, slightly brown.   Flavor - Initially tart fruit, but floral hop flavor mixed in with a strong alcohol flavor dominate.  Very smooth lasting finish.  fuller bodied than it appears.  Tastes similar to Unibroue's La Maudite but not as strong.  Overall very good, would definitely buy again.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 Clear amber with a medium diminishing white head.  Malt, caramel, pear, nut and apple aromas abound. Medium watery body with a moderate amount of carbonation. The flavor is nice with nut, caramel and bread notes dominating with honey, pear and spice in the background. It starts out a little thin and sweet, but the flavor becomes more complex for a nice spicy finish.  Refreshing, a great session beer.

Not your typical Oktoberfest - not as malty and sweet as some. Slight malty aroma, fresh. Light copper appearance, spongy off-white head. Has a bit of a light caramel twang to it. Slight hop bitterness mixes in well to balance it out - that's what I like about this one. Very refereshing, could see myself in Munich hoisting a few of these. They go down very easily. Very smooth mouthfeel and finish. Overall, a very well done beer.

This beer had a average sized smooth and creamy ivory head when poured and it had fine-small sized bubbles that mostly diminished. The body was carbonated and cloudy with a golden hue. The nose consisted of malt, caramel, and fruits with a light bitter, hoppy and sour flavor to it. The mouthfeel was smooth and thin and it was medium bodied. This beer left a good lacing on the sides of my glass.

An understated and drinkable beer, perfect for the BBQ, tailgate or fishing cooler.  Dry, pale malt and musky yeast aroma with some nutty sweetness. Has an initial sweet burst on the tip of the tongue, followed by good pale malt flavors, almost like a lagered bitter, medium bittering and a residual very light sweetness. Medium body, some tinny/burnt twinges in the finish.  The finish builds, but remains satisfying.

An amber colored body beneath a thin eggshell head.  The aroma is quite malty.  Sweet and nutty with hints of whole grains, raisin, a touch of alcohol, wheatabix, and maybe a mushy apple.  Clean and crisp despite sparse, random hints metallic notes.  A tasty, flavorful example of the style.

This brew poured a small head of off-white colored fine to medium sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lacing and a hazy light brown colored carbonated body.  It has a boring malt hop aroma and a bubbly tingly mouthfeel.  The flavor was malty and buttery.
Color is amber with a small frothy head. Flavor is sweet with nutty notes. Flavor is sweet with spicy notes. This brewery has some very good brews.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Very nice!  Sweet, smooth malt with some sort of spice in the background.  Nice mouthfeel.  The touch of hops feels just right.  Try this one out, I don't think you'll be disapointed!

Got the remaining one of these when I was looking for the Octoberfest beers, I found that this beer was a wonderful subsitution. The light copper hue was topped by a small but tight head and good lace was produced. Aroma hinted of caramel malts, apples, butterscotch, and floral hops. Some hint of vanilla and smoke also detected on the nose. The taste was heavy malty sweey at the start but a refreshing hoppy twang and sour fruit tone came through midway. The finish was surprisingly clean and mildly bitter. This medium-bodied brew had a smooth mouthfeel. This is yet another Capital brew I will recommend, highly quaffable.

Far and away the best Marzen I've ever had. Perfectly smooth, incredibly drinkable, perfect blend of flavors. Nothing more to really say. I don't know what else is out there but it's probably not better than this. This one makes one of my original points that Wisconsin makes the best beer.
Golden, almost reddish beer with a nice head.  Hints of apple in the malty nose.  Seemingly fresh for a Marzen enjoyed on Labor Day.  Nice rich malts through the middle and finishes slightly bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 Read the commercial description.  This is great, I've had it draft and bottle in Madison. Anyway, pour it into your glass and make a toast with your friends.  ... I DO remember it being greeeaaat.

Tried this first out on the dock, with the brew warm out of the bottle and had an unpleasantly heavy, syrupy malt experience. Later, indoors playing sheepshead, I poured out a much more pleasant brew.  The malts are strong and distinct, definitely leaning heavy, but they are generously accompanied by a bitter bite of hops.  Good stuff.

Malty aroma, but somewhat off...like sweaty socks. Large, off-white head. Light amber body with dark tan head. Slow but substantial carbonation. Thin but very good lace. Malty falvor with some banana notes. Plain and average, but a good attempt. Note that this brew might be past its prime, as I purchased it in July and it is a Spring seasonal.

Nice amber color good carbonation,small head that was quick to fade leaving little behind.Malty aroma almost a mild wheat tone to it as well,fruity and mildly spiced.Nice malt taste with a mild fruit presence and decent hopping,mildly sweet with an after taste that is sweet and mild hops nice feel in the mouth.This is a pretty decent brew and a nice addition to this guys tasting exp.

Tap at brewery-Aroma was definately that of german malts and grains/hints of fall-appearance was copper/pale red-flavor was nice malt, spice, and german hops.  palate was a bit thin and little carbonation.  if those would have been better, it would be a world class marzen by far.
Not great or extraordinary, but not bad either.  I won't hurry back to get more of this, but I'm not sorry I tried it.
This was good. Not overly impressive, but good. Head didn't last long, but had some lacing along the way. No bad aftertaste nor bitterness. Worth a try.

Color is a caramel brown of lighter tone, creamy thin and light tannish head that fades to leave dripping stringy lace. Smell is a roasty malt with a touch of light fruity sweetness. Taste is pale and a bit crispy of roasted malts with a short astringency and hop bite of clean bitterness thats nicely balanced and tolerable into the finish. Medium body, finishing of mild bitterness, crisp and quite refreshing. One excellent drinker and would make for a good session brew.
Nice thick off white foamy head.Reddish copper in color. Sweet malty, banana peel, slightly nutty flavor. Sweet aftertaste. Thick mouthfeel. I liked this very much.

Very crisp and clean.  Golden /copper color with a white head.  This may sound weird but I am reminded of a wheat when I smell and taste this beer, without the banana.  This is a very good summer beer.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2003 A good brew. I have to say that I enjoyed this one.  I was feeling festiv when I had this brew,and I had it in the middle of winter at that. Damn did it make it feel like summer though.
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2003 Golden body, kind of thin, no head.  Sweet caramel & great barley aroma and flavor, Hints of vanilla as well. tasty stuff.  Mildly astrinent, clean acidic finish.  Good balance.
Very good beer.  Slightly sweet, but not overly so.  Nice malt flavors with hops peeking in at the end, good balance.  A solid Märzen.
Nice sweet flavor in the copper colored body.  It has a fairly complex maltiness with a fresh floral hoppy finish.  This is a very drinkable oktoberfest with lots of character.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2003 golden clear, slight carbonation, very thin head. malty kind of bready aroma...not much there, but the flavor has a decent hop presence.
re-rate: what i didnt originally realize was that there are a LOT of hops in both the aroma and flavor.
Orangish color, with a thick tan colored head. Sweet smelling. Lightly sweet taste. Dry aftertaste. Id drink it again.
Extremely smooth, with a very nice malty flavor, with a little hint of liquorice/anise.  Not amazing, but very solid.
My favorite daily beer. Smooth and tasty with a wonderful clean afer taste. I missed it when it goes out of season.

As I understand it, a fest beer is different than an Oktoberfestbier.  Well, it tasted pretty damn similiar to be.  Still very sweet but not missing the hop flavor that I love so much.  Beautiful amber color with a clean, short lived white head.

I may not always like what this brewery comes up with, but its not for lack of quality, but rather personal taste.  That said, this Festbier is a tasty winner.  Sweeter than expected and mildly hopped Id give it very high marks indeed if youre into this style.
Sweet in a good way--lots of malt in here and just a trace of hoppiness.  Goes down very smoothly.  It would be easy to put many of these away in one sitting...
sweet sweet malts - caramel and apple cider, but not overly sweet like some fests; this one is backed up by a lightly biting hop.
Sweet honey and malt dominate the palate.  Dark yet refreshing - a great mix - I would definitely try this again!

Now were getting somewhere. Part of the Capital Summer Sampler, this is a really good seasonal. Dark amber with decent lace. Nice honey and nutty aroma. Tastes kind of like a Marzen with a malt flavor and light caramel finish. I will look for this one next summer.

The beer poured a copper amber color and formed an amazing off white foamy head that left some nice lace. An aroma of hops and spices like clove. It had a taste of hops, caramel and clove. Almost reminded more of a specilty or brown ale style. Thats what makes there non-description of this beer confusing. I am not sure what its trying to be. Not a bad beer though.
Very attractive beer from the tap: appropriately dry, very flavorful, and a rich body that complements its heritage. Perhaps a little too much on the yeasty side, but I quibble.
Great golden-amber color,nice sweetness very dry clean finish, another great beer by this brewery.

Frothy white foam with decent stick but great retention.  Amber liquid.  The very clean aroma boasts honey, toastiness, yeastiness, and fruitiness.  Flavors lean toward sweetness, with spices being displayed wonderfully.  This could suffice as another Maibock.  These guys continue to impress me with their very straightforward philosophy, yet unprecedented lager/ale creating knack.  Well done, Capital.  I am not so sure this is an ale.  This brewery really erks me, however.  They offer no information, other than the name of the beer, not the style.  What on Earth is a Fest?!!  They also have the most unattractive labels I have yet seen.  The label shows a CapitOl, not a CapitAl.  Confusing, to me.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 2002 Version. A much better effort than in the last few years.  Maibock maltiness with a slightly more aggressive hop schedule. Golden colored.  NIce smooth feel.
A little too hoppy on the swallow for my liking but its not too bad.
